INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being slightly past 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to see that the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) is in the chamber tonight while I discuss this issue. This issue is deserving of his support. I noticed that in an adjournment speech last week the member for Paterson bleated about an intersection in his electorate, the problems of which would be overcome entirely if he would only support me on this proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I am referring to a road project which links the F3 freeway and a point of the New England Highway just north of Branxton, which is in my electorate. The Kurri Corridor, as it is known, if constructed would provide enormous benefits to my electorate, the electorate of Paterson and many other electorates beyond those. The $220 million project is certainly deserving of the support of all members serving in this House.

This would relieve the Cessnock, Newcastle and Maitland councils of problems associated with the presence of national highway traffic. The main roads in the township of Cessnock, including those in the central business district, have effectively been a de facto national highway since Easter 1988. The proportion of national highway traffic which does not short cut through Cessnock is a nightmare for residents living on Weekley's Drive, Beresfield, and residents of Maitland East and Maitland West. Those residents attempt to access the national highway via the Chelmsford Drive intersection, which the member for Paterson referred to during his adjournment speech last week.

The townships of Lochinvar, Greta and Branxton would all receive relief from national highway traffic as a result of the construction of the Kurri Corridor. The new found proximity of the Upper Hunter, with all its coal and agricultural product, to Sydney and the port of Newcastle would provide an enormous boost to that part of my electorate.

What are the chances of the Kurri Corridor being constructed? What are the odds following the coalition's decision to cut $622 million from the national highway budget over the next four years? Mr Speaker, I remind you that this is a cut to a budget which is of the order of $840 million a year. We are talking about a very significant cut. My fear is that the odds are about one million to one. It is a very tragic decision for all the reasons I have already outlined. It is a tragic decision because of the loss of benefits which the residents in the Paterson electorate would have gained from the construction of the Kurri Corridor. The failure of the Howard government to commit itself to the Kurri Corridor is causing more immediate concerns. People living along the path of the road link are in limbo.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the former government?

—The former government was committed to it. People like Keith Thomas on Cessnock Road, Branxton, Valda McCloughlin of Lovedale and John Pyne and others living on Avery Lane, Buchanan, are in limbo. They do not know whether in the next five years or so a freeway will run over the ground on which their houses now stand. They cannot sell their homes or their properties. Mr Speaker, would you or the member for Paterson buy a property with such an extensive proposal hanging over its head? I think not. In my view, these people should be effectively compensated from the EIS stage of the development of the highway. The RTA would not lose any money because if the freeway did not proceed they could resell the properties and recoup their money.

SPEECH.PARA: The dilemmas do not end there. Cessnock council's legal advice indicated that whenever it is considering a development application it must consider the implications of the freeway on the development and the effects of the development on the freeway. The council's problems do not end there. The council is desperate to refurbish its struggling central business district but it cannot properly do so because of the existence of that heavy vehicle traffic that uses the main street of Cessnock as a de facto national highway.

It cannot attract state government funding for a simple bypass while the Kurri Corridor hangs over its head. It is a real catch 22 situation for Cessnock council. What Cessnock council and the people of my community need is an unequivocal statement from the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) as to whether or not he supports this project. I support the project and I will continue to support the project. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today, I reported in the grievance debate that an Aboriginal community school called Culunga has serious concerns relating to its accountability in educational terms and its many forms of maladministration. This school is largely funded by DEETYA moneys hence the Commonwealth has a great interest in the functioning of this school.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to point out one of the areas of concern. The DEETYA funds are currently also used for homework classes. These homework classes cost something like $35 an hour and are provided after school. I am reliably informed that these funds are not used for homework classes. A BBQ is put on and the rest of the kids roam around the school. The people who are supposed to be teaching do not teach. Even more seriously, one of the people who was to receive these homework class moneys was in gaol at the time. He was in gaol for some time while he was still being paid the funds to teach homework classes after school.

Other concerns, which I gave a great history of this afternoon, are that the family members of the board pay each other in cash, for which there is, apparently, also no accountability. On 29 January 1997, nothing had changed. The school coordinator asked the chairperson of the board, who just happens to be her sister, for a cash advance. She said that she had run out of money over the Christmas break. She was told, `I will go and check.' Ten minutes later she was told, `Yes, you can have it; try and pay it back in December 1997.'

Earlier today I also referred to two documents. One was the letter from the school principal to the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations and another was the letter from the Australian Government Solicitor, which did an audit into the school. I seek leave to table those documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Funds of ASSPA, which stands for Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness, are also under scrutiny at this school. There are many allegations that these funds are not being spent on the Abo riginal students there and that in fact funds are being siphoned off in a rather dubious manner.

SPEECH.PARA: For these reasons and many others that I alluded to today, I call for an independent inquiry into the running and administration of this school, in particular in relation to its funds and the quality of education it provides, so that the children of this school can get a fair go. They are at a special Aboriginal school to get a special Aboriginal program, and the funds are not going where they are designed to go. Whether this inquiry is initiated through the many committees of this parliament or is determined independently in another forum, I would hope that the minister would take that request on board. There are allegations of gross impropriety regarding the funding of this school in particular.

Another serious allegation is that as of last Friday, the remaining two Aboriginal teachers at this school were sacked; they were given notice. These were the two teachers who have spoken out. It seems rather unusual to me that the two remaining very well qualified Aboriginal teachers who have come forward and spoken out are now being told that their services will not be required in six weeks time. That would leave the school with very few pupils and a skeleton staff to try to run the school.

If the school is going to be run on a skeleton staff with a handful of students, why should the school remain open when there are more appropriate schools locally? There is another Aboriginal school up the road run by Robert Bropho; there are Aboriginal programs in surrounding high schools and primary schools where the needs of the Aboriginal children are being met. I call on the minister and all those who are responsible to conduct an inquiry into the running of this school forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I want to raise is about Belmont wetlands in my electorate. I have raised this matter in the House on a number of previous occasions and I will continue to do so. Between Belmont and Redhead in my electorate there was once a unique coastal wetland. That was until BHP gained control of the surface rights of the land in the 1960s.

SPEECH.PARA: BBHP—Before BHP—the wetlands, the high sand dune systems backing Nine Mile Beach, the continuous coastal wetland system, collected the run‐off from the Dudley, Whitebridge, Charlestown, Gateshead and Tingira Heights ridges and valleys. It filtered down through creeks and ponds into the only coastal wetlands system in our region. The 1892 maps showed that some of the water reached the sea by a creek at the northern end of Nine Mile Beach and some eventually reached Lake Macquarie via Belmont Lagoon and various connecting marshlands.

The Australian Army map of 1941 shows the coastal dune system in the area in all its glory, with dune heights ranging from 15 feet along the back of the beach to a hundred feet further inland. The area was a unique coastal dune wetlands system, the jungle like conditions of which were utilised by the Australian Army to train troops for service in the Pacific during World War II.

BHP has presided over the devastation of this once beautiful strip of coastal wetlands and dunes. First they mined the coal from beneath at Lambton B and John Darling collieries, which are now both closed. In the 1960s the sand dunes were mined for minerals. Up to this day sand has been continued to be removed and sold from what was once a beautiful section of Australia's coastline.

Where the hundred feet sand dunes stood the level is now flat. The fringes of the area are used as a rubbish dump by numerous people. People drive through there and see the rubbish on the edge and think, `This is rubbish land.' They would never go inside behind the rubbish to see what was once inside.

The reaction of BHP has been to mount the feeble excuse that now that the area has been devastated and despoiled, it should be rezoned to enable residential development and some wetlands refurbishment to take place. This would enable BHP to make a limited restoration of some wetlands and to construct some 1,400 homes in a fragile, sensitive, low lying area between the east side of Lake Macquarie and the sea. It would create a huge windfall profit for BHP—in fact, a reward for its supervision of wanton destruction of a precious piece of our coastline.

A local government study has been carried out. Public responses were invited by Lake Macquarie City Council. In my view these public responses and concerns have been treated, in the main, in a cavalier and unprofessional manner by council officers. When one reads through them one cannot help but form the conclusion that the council officers see their role as being dedicated to ensuring that BHP's application gets through.

No attempt has been made to present an alternative utilisation of that coastal wetlands system and the council itself appears to be compliant towards BHP. In fact, some councillors are in awe of, even intimidated by, BHP. Strangest of all strangeness, the beach is owned by BHP. I cannot discover how BHP came to own nine miles of Australia's beach, but they own the beach. Some of the councillors say to me, `Don't make too much noise, because they may not give us the beach back.' The beach is riven by undertows. It is a very dangerous beach on which to swim; it is little utilised. It is a good fishing beach with gutters but a very dangerous area for swimming.

So my response has been to invite BHP to try to fence off the beach. If you want the beach, put a barbed wire fence around it like you did during the war when it was a defence system. But the company has presided over the destruction of one of our most beautiful areas of coastline. Having made coal profits, beach mineral royalties, sandmining royalties and income from the area, it now asks for more. Suddenly, another arm of BHP, BHP Titanium Minerals Pty Ltd, has lodged an exploration notice for heavy minerals over the same area.

I had hoped that BHP would accept a responsible attitude towards this and hand that land, or lease it, back to public ownership so it could be redeveloped over time for future Australians. It has the potential to become a beautiful coastal wetlands system again, a system of national and international standing that could rank as a major tourist attraction and a major recreational and leisure resource for Australians. So I think that BHP should be putting something back into the area it has devastated and that council should be rejecting outright the application for rezoning.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Member for Forde: Parliamentary Activities Youth Unemployment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elson, Kay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to clarify a few newspaper articles that appeared in various daily newspapers this morning. The articles are trying to place some significance on the number of times that I and other colleagues have spoken in this chamber. They have wrongly asserted that I have not caught the Speaker's eye since making my maiden speech. I have in fact spoken in this parliament on 11 different occasions. I have participated actively in question time, which is, as we all know, the most well‐attended and lively debate in this chamber. I also strongly refute the implication in these articles that I am in some way the silent type. As anyone who knows me will attest, I am not shy in having my say.

SPEECH.PARA: My aim is always to achieve results for the people of my electorate of Forde. Since being elected, I have tended to make a more direct approach and very often I have organised meetings and had discussions with ministers directly on issues of concern to my constituents. This tends to get results quicker than waiting for the legislation to be debated in this House. I do not for one moment decry the processes of this House, but I believe it is an unreal assessment to look at speeches in this chamber as a measurement of performance. Performance by anyone's measure is about results and, as many ministers will attest, I am tenacious in pushing and achieving results for Forde.

As we all know in this place, there are many ways of doing your job in Canberra. I am an active of member of seven committees. There are two standing committees—employment, education and training and family and community affairs—and five government committees, which are health and family services; veterans affairs; industry, small busi ness, science and tourism; environment, sport, territories, local government and social security and primary industries and energy. As we all know, government legislation and policy are discussed at these committees before it is introduced in the parliament. That is where, I believe, I can have the most impact and make the changes that benefit the people of Forde.

I am by nature a no‐nonsense person. I make no apologies for the fact that I have concentrated my efforts here in Canberra on where I can make the biggest impact. With the greatest respect for the institution of this parliament, in the vast majority of cases that is not in this chamber speaking after legislation has been finalised. I know that the local residents whom I meet at my regular open days in regional areas around the electorate, those I have helped by direct contact with ministers and departments and the many thousands I have met in my office and at functions will appreciate that my efforts over the past 12 months have been directed at doing my job and producing results.

I would like to take the time in this debate to comment on an issue of great concern throughout my electorate and on which I have been working with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training—that is, youth unemployment. It is difficult to overstate the level of community support there is for the government's work for the dole scheme. People recognise it for what it is: the chance to keep young people involved, restore their confidence and self-esteem, build their work ethic and give them real hope for the future. I have spoken with many communities and business groups in Forde who are champing at the bit to get involved in work for the dole, and I have encouraged them to do so.

I have made a protest to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) asking that the pilot programs be conducted in the regional areas of Beaudesert and Boonah. It is important that as a government we are prepared to tackle the tough problems, those that the previous government left in the too‐hard basket. I am pleased to be part of a government which, like me, is results orientated and takes the direct approach people want and expect: commonsense and action from their parliamentarians, not just talk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr ADAMS

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak in this adjournment debate, and I would like to discuss the government's new nursing home policy, which I believe is a fundamental attack on the aged people of Australia. I have had a lot of people write to and ring me and people have visited me at my office concerning this policy and concerning what the government intends to put onto the Australian aged population.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I had somebody come into my office who is getting on in her life now, but her story is very typical. I knew her husband for many years, but he passed on some years ago. He left home as a pretty young man and worked for many years in the mountain ranges of Tasmania building hydro‐electric schemes till he raised enough money to build himself a small business in a country town. He was a small shopkeeper. He and his wife toiled for the rest of their lives. When they sold their small business, they bought a small cottage and a couple of acres so they could run the pony for the granddaughter. That was what he wanted to do, and that was what he did in his life.

As I said, he passed on and his wife now lives in that cottage. Now the pressure is starting to come. Her time is getting close to when she will need to go into a nursing home. She is getting very frail and she will need a nursing home bed. Her last dream and her last goals in life, I suppose, are to leave that cottage to her family and to her grandchildren. That dream and those goals have now been taken away by this government. It is stretching it and it is pulling away from the commitment that it should have to aged Australia.

There are many, many people who cannot, and will not be able to, afford a nursing home bed. The government is not outlining how these people are going to cope. It has not given these people an opportunity to under stand its ideas, its policy. It is trying to con the people.

This was not a part of your platform at the last election. None of you people went out and said to the people of Australia, `You will have to sell your house to get a nursing home bed.' None of you went out to the electorate, and do not say you did because none of you did. You failed the people of Australia, and now you are tearing their houses off them so they can get a nursing home bed. That is what you are doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're scaring them.
—I am not scaring anybody. People are contacting me with their concerns. What am I supposed to say to them?
—Advance the debate, don't try to scare them in the process.

—I am not scaring them. I am trying to tell them what you people are trying to do. It is very difficult to get information from the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan). It is very hard to get the detail of what you are doing to the aged people of Australia.
—No answers.

—There are no answers. You talk about accommodation. It is not accommodation these people need. Sixty per cent of them come out of acute hospitals and into nursing home beds—60 per cent of them! This is not about hiring a flat or going into a flat. This is not even about going into a hostel. This is about a nursing home bed. This is about decisions that have to be made by these people at a time in their lives which is not easy for them or their families.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, trying to get details and information to give to people is very difficult. Your minister has come along to the table when asked questions in question time, but she has refused to answer them. She introduced a bill in the House the other day, but she refuses to answer many of the queries put to her by members on our side of the House. She is going along but she will not face what she is doing or what this government is trying to force on the aged people of Australia.

BREAK.PARA: Those people who will have to deal with this issue are finding it very difficult to get information. I can assure all members of the government that you will cop it from your own electorates, because people are starting to seek out information about what you are doing to them but they cannot get it. That is a failure of this government. This government has attacked the aged people of Australia but they are not producing the detail. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise an important issue tonight regarding the fruit industry in Australia. I refer to the President of the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association, Jon Durham, who has spoken about the proposal by New Zealand to export apples into Australia. A recent newspaper article quoted Mr Durham as saying that fire blight, a disease which is apparently in evidence in New Zealand:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . could hit Australian crops by the year 2006 if New Zealand's application to the Federal Government was successful.
The article continued:
He said the fire blight clock would start ticking from the first shipment.
"There is a one-in-20 chance that fire blight will become established in Australia within the first 10 years of trade with New Zealand," he said.
If introduced to Australia, fire blight has the capacity to reduce net returns for apple growers by 25 per cent and pear growers by 40 per cent.
Mr Durham went on to say that:
The whole canning industry is at risk, as are full‐time and casual jobs in the industry.

I want to point out to the House that within my electorate is the district of Harcourt, which has one of the biggest apple industries in Australia. That is in the bottom half of my electorate. Just north of my electorate in the federal seat of Murray is a very substantial pear industry.

I am concerned about this proposal. I want to say that the government should give this matter their most urgent consideration because, if fire blight does get into Australia, it would be to the detriment of the whole fruit industry. Australia enjoys a very good reputa tion overseas for having clean agricultural product. If that reputation were tarnished in any way, it would be to the detriment of Australia and particularly our fruit industry.

The newspaper article continued by quoting Mr Durham as saying that gross farm income was expected to fall by at least $20 million if their fears were confirmed—that is, if those apples did come in and the spread of fire blight disease did take place. Mr Durham said:
. . . fire blight, an exotic disease, could cause troubles similar to the Queensland papaya fruit fly problem.
Members from Queensland would understand the difficulties associated with that particular problem. Mr Durham went on to say that:
. . . the New Zealand application failed to guarantee fire blight would not be introduced if their apples were allowed access to Australia.

I raise this issue in the adjournment debate so that it will be considered by the government. I notice that the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) is in the chamber, and I am sure he will take note of my comments. He represents Tasmania and they have a substantial apple industry in Tasmania. I know he will take note of my comments and deliver my concerns to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and also to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson).

This weekend the Harcourt district will be holding their Applefest, which is a celebration of the high quality apples produced in that area. I hope I will be in attendance at that apple festival to help them celebrate the fine quality apples they produce.

DEBATE.TITLE:
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS BILL 1996 Cognate bills: RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by Mr Prosser:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to resume the debate on the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1996, the Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996, and the Retirement Savings Accounts Supervisory Levy Bill 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: Another group of individuals who may potentially benefit from retirement savings accounts are those persons close to retirement who may wish to minimise risk. Due to their capital protected nature, RSAs may be particularly attractive to those who in no way want to risk negative investment returns.

Employers who are looking for a convenient superannuation vehicle for small contributions under the superannuation guarantee arrangements will also benefit from the provisions of RSAs. Also, RSA providers will likewise benefit from being able to offer cost efficient delivery of superannuation and from enhanced customer relationships through the provision of one-stop shop services.
Let me note that the coalition has long pushed for more choices in superannuation.
Mr Price interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Chifley will be speaking soon. He will reserve his comments until then.

—In fact, as far back as the late 1980s when we were in opposition, something that the honourable member for Chifley will become familiar with, we were suggesting the implementation of retirement savings accounts. However, the Labor Party wanted no part of retirement savings accounts. Why? It was because the ACTU was opposed to them.

SPEECH.PARA: The ACTU has been opposed to RSAs because under industrial award superannuation the ACTU got a say in the management of superannuation. Industrial awards do not generally allow for individual employees to make a decision on the fund where their contributions will be invested. The ACTU, and thus the Labor Party because they are hand in glove, have been happy leaving workers out of superannuation decisions altogether. That is a funny thing for a party that fancies itself as standing up for the rights of workers.

One of the more distinguishing features of the RSA is that it will be required to be capital guaranteed, meaning that the amounts invested cannot be reduced due to negative investment returns. Subject to any fixed term of interest payments on the deposit accounts, funds in retirement savings accounts will be fully portable. That is, an RSA provider will be required to transfer part or all of an account to another RSA or superannuation fund at the account holder's request. Either an account member, or an employer on an account member's behalf, will be able to make contributions to an RSA.

By virtue of their capital guaranteed nature, it is generally expected that the returns offered by RSAs will be less than those offered by other superannuation providers. For this reason a number of individuals and industry groups wanted the legislation to provide for a maximum amount that can be invested in an RSA. I draw this to the attention of the member for Chifley who scoffs at the suggestion that this is a positive reaction to what the workers want, to what the people want. May I suggest that the opposition follow our direction and you too, one day, some day, long into the future, well after the member for Chifley has retired, may be given another opportunity on the Treasury benches.

The government wishes to ensure that people's retirement incomes are maximised and it recognises that for some people RSAs may be an appropriate choice. The government strongly believes that restrictions on the amount that can be invested in RSAs are contrary to its policy of greater choice in superannuation and thus there will be no restriction on RSA balances.

Nevertheless, it will be mandatory for RSA providers to advise account holders of alternative balanced portfolio products offering potentially higher returns over the longer term when their balances reach $10,000. The government believes that this adequately addresses concerns regarding the expected low return from RSAs as compared to an investment based superannuation fund. Ultimately, account holders will be informed of investment options and will be able to choose if they wish to maintain their funds in a retirement savings account.

The supervision of retirement savings accounts is divided into two parts. First, the prudential supervision for institutional soundness of the RSA provider will be carried out under existing regulatory frameworks regarding, amongst other things, capital requirements and liquidity management. For example, in the case of banks, the prudential regulator is the Reserve Bank of Australia. Perhaps the Wallis inquiry will make a separate recommendation. In the case of building societies and credit unions, the prudential regulator is the Australian Financial Institutions Commission, AFIC, and state supervisory authorities.

The second regulatory element is functional supervision for compliance with retirement income and other non-prudential superannuation standards. These standards, which ensure that RSAs are maintained for genuine retirement purposes and provide for a well‐informed membership, will be carried out by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Again, that is subject to the government's decision about the outcome and recommendations of the Wallis report.

It is the government's intent that the treatment of RSAs with regard to superannuation standards is as consistent as possible with that applying to existing superannuation products. For this reason, this bill is closely modelled on relevant provisions of the regulatory regime applicable to superannuation under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. Does the honourable member for Chifley remember that one?

BREAK.PARA: Finally, it is worth noting that, in connection with the preparation of this legislation, the government undertook substantial consultation with the relevant industry and consumer groups. Further consultation will be sought with regard to promulgating the regulations under the legislation.

It goes without saying that the primary purpose of superannuation is to provide individuals with a better income in retirement. This coalition government recognises that, in order to cope with the costs of the ageing population, it must encourage people to save throughout their working lives for their own retirement.

This bill, along with the government's other superannuation reform initiatives, provides a framework for a fairer and more flexible superannuation system that more readily meets the differing circumstances of individual Australians and, at the end of the day, encourages savings. This framework goes a long way towards addressing the serious flaws in the superannuation system that were left to us after 13 years of very hard Labor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that we are having this debate in the parliament. I think it comes about for much more significant reasons than may be understood by the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) and a number of his colleagues. In recent Australian history—and by that I mean post-World War II—superannuation has had a sad history of conservative governments neither understanding the need for it in the Australian economy nor understanding how they could bring it about.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember my father talking about the great vision of Chifley. The member for Chifley (Mr Price) would be very interested in this. His vision in 1947 was to establish the national superannuation fund or pension fund into which the nation all agreed to pay a small percentage of their pay. That was the first real vision of national superannuation.

We still have—and you would be aware of this yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker—old‐timers coming along and making the case that they believe a pension is a right. They reject the notion of an assets test and an income test, because they still believe what they were told back in 1948 that if they invested in this national pension scheme they would have a pension for life.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what happened to it?

—I will tell you. Having established this national pension fund, the Menzies government, elected in 1949, under advice from Treasury, the banking system and the emerging life insurance corporations, immediately took that advice that a better way to encourage Australians to save was to go via the route of home ownership by encouraging them to take out home loans and by giving them tax deductions for interest on home loans. More significantly, they were encouraged down the life insurance road and given significant tax reductions if they contributed to life assurance and other insurance products.

SPEECH.PARA: Bear in mind that this was in the days of a tax regime where the highest income earners had a 60c in the dollar marginal tax rate. So the tax deductions that high income earners got for these contributions were much higher than those of ordinary working people. It evolved that white‐collar public servants had access to superannuation as we know it, and executives in businesses had access to superannuation, but increasingly further down the income scale, the less disposable income people had, and most of it was committed to purchasing a home.

Very little money was left over to contribute to these other savings products and, therefore, there were no tax deductions. What evolved was a savings system based around high income earners providing for their future and home ownership, and middle and low income earners remaining reliant upon a pension.

Whitlam saw the error of this and had another go at instituting national superannuation. We would all remember quite vividly the strident campaigns that were run against Whitlam by the conservatives and the banking and insurance industries against national superannuation. With a Senate that was not prepared to pass his legislation, he also failed.

So it continued until Labor's productivity trade‐off with the trade union movement in 1986—opposed by those on the other side in the parliament at every step, and opposed by employers as a tax on jobs—which led to the first three per cent contribution to this superannuation pool.

I want to mention something that very few people ever talk about or understand about this. As a government at that time we successfully communicated to the general public the need for superannuation to provide for pensions for the future and the need to wean people off the public pension system. That is not a problem—everyone agrees with retirement income policy.

However, what nobody understood was that the major deficiency in the structure of the Australian economy—and what was needed to give us some structural independence, to give us some opportunity to buy back the farm, to give us some opportunity to wean ourselves off overseas borrowing—was a long‐term `patient' capital base.

When Labor started this process of national superannuation in 1986, there was $40 billion in the super pool in Australia—mostly from white‐collar workers, public sector workers and executives—in the likes of National Mutual and AMP. That figure now stands at a staggering $350 billion. For those who run around fretting about Australia's foreign debt, Australia's net foreign debt is $180 billion. So twice the amount of foreign debt is already in the superannuation pool.

TALK.START.PARA: —$500 billion by the year 2000?
—It will be much more than that. It will be much more than $500 billion. The member for Chifley is always conservative about these estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: Part of the challenge that the economy faces is the marshalling of this $350 billion plus to get it active in the economy. Labor's vision for it did embrace a lot of these strategies, and I will come to retirement savings accounts in this context in just a minute.

There were some aspects of this pool which should have been activated in our economy a long time before now. We hear a lot about falling interest rates for home loans. We hear a lot of preaching about competition in the finance sector and how wonderful it is. Of course it is. But where did it come from? Aussie Home Loans did not appear from nowhere.

Aussie Home Loans is a securitising organisation that is funded in the vast majority by investments now being made by these pools. The arrangements that were made with the superannuation funds at the time of the productivity trade‐off was that one of their first products would be cheaper home loans for members, at least one per cent below the Commonwealth Bank rate.

It is a matter of great irritation to me that it took them eight years to deliver. It was not as if these fund managers suddenly produced some fabulous new product for Australia that attracted the whole investment industry to them. People were made to put their money in these funds. There were five main goals. Home loans for the contributing members was one of these goals. That has now started to roll out very well. Because of the failure of the banks in this sector, small business finance was another. I notice that Aussie Loans is about to become Aussie Business Loans. There was supposed to be a proactive productive investment in the Australian economy in terms of refinancing large overseas borrowings in the private sector. They are only just starting to get interested in that now.

Infrastructure bonds were created for these people to come and invest in infrastructure in the Australian economy. For four years they sat around wondering how to do it and whether they should. The new treasurer has had to rule the line off them because the demand has become too great for infrastructure bonds. They have all rushed there now, and he is cutting it off.

So, on it goes. The most serious need in the Australian economy was proactive venture capital for the small and medium business sector. Why was it necessary for a Labor government to do all this with the providers of superannuation funds? I will tell you; it was because the banking system had failed. The banking system either did not understand the problem, let alone the answer, or it was not interested in these areas. The failure of the banking system is the principal reason. Those on the other side might go on about trade union trustees having control of money—that has always been something that they have been paranoid about. The industry funds are only a minor proportion of this $350 billion. It is there as of today. It is a paranoia about nothing. The paranoia on the part of the government ought to be about the failure of these funds to proactively drive investment in the Australian economy, which was the intention. It is falling out slowly and it will happen. Where were the banks in all this?

We made a very deliberate decision. Banks have not shown the skills or the expertise or the interest in marshalling and using long‐term patient capital. Remember that a lot of people on the other side of politics talked about superannuation as a tax on jobs. All those sorts of reasons were used to say why we should not do it. In Singapore, 40 per cent of the national payroll now goes into superannuation. Workers pay in 20 per cent and employers pay in 20 per cent. Employees borrow back for their home loans and all of their repayments go back into the funds. Employers borrow from the funds to expand their businesses and all their repayments go back. Singapore does not owe anybody a cracker.

That vision of patient capital was Labor's vision, and still remains our vision. But we were not interested in having the banks in it—they felt that very bitterly—and so evolved the concept of retirement savings accounts. Yes, the super funds abused the early phases of this with small accounts and transient workers moving from one workplace to another, all those teething problems. They did rip people off with charges but they stopped doing it as soon as it was made clear that accounts with a balance of under $1,000 would be moved to the tax office, and that people would be paid the Treasury rate of interest, not charged costs.

The choice is there, very broadly, now but what we really have is retirement savings accounts with banks and no trustees. If you invest in these funds, you do not have any say in who is managing them but you can remove your funds and take them to another institution. That is your ultimate consumer choice. Why on earth would a government want to create a vehicle for people to save in but not give them trustees, unless they do not want people to have a say in it? Who does not want them to have a say in it? Obviously, the board and senior management of the banks.

Make no mistake about it, this is opening a very big door for the banks, because they had been squeezed out of $350 billion. They paid their price and now they are getting their payback. By that, I mean, very straightforwardly and very bluntly, the banks were not the Liberal Party's major campaign donors in the last election campaign for nothing. We all understand there is no such thing as a free lunch in politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a bit like the unions, your major contributors.

—Absolutely. You are paranoid about the unions. You can be; it does not worry me in the least. This mob were not your biggest donors for no reason. The price was RSAs. If you do not find that convincing go and read the article in The Independent of March last year headed `Ron's Party'. That is the article about Ron Walker, the federal treasurer for the Liberal Party, going into the National Bank and getting something that I have never heard of in Australia; an unsecured personal loan of $10 million to fund the Liberal Party's election campaign, when the organisation was bankrupt under Downer and no‐one was prepared to put a cracker in. Ron walks in and says, `We're going to unload him; we're going to bring back John and, by the way, you can have RSAs. We'll let you into super.' He got the $10 million unsecured personal loan.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that this article has been published for two years and never once has anyone, from Andrew Robb down, protested in any way about it because the facts of it are correct. The Liberal Party was given a $10 million unsecured loan from the National Bank, on Ron's word. According to this article, and according to the comments of a number of members of the Liberal Party, a lot of people in the Liberal Party were very unhappy about it. The article states:
A federal Liberal parliamentarian—
it can't be you, Mr Deputy Speaker, you are a National Party member—
who has a detailed knowledge of federal and state party financing says, "It's totally outrageous. That's how you buy a political party."
The article goes on:
A senior shadow minister—
I assume now a minister—

who knew of the undertaking claims it was significant because the party "might not be able to get rid of him". This, he believes, could have implications for policy. "Walker is somebody who needs to be kept under control because otherwise he will try to use the power of the dollar to influence decisions of the party".

That is the fact of it. The banks were bitterly stunned by Labor saying to them, `You have a long‐term history of a lack of understanding and a lack of interest in the role of patient capital in the Australian economy.'

Through the 1980s and the surge of investment during the boom and deregulation, the banks did not acquit themselves all that successfully. So why on earth would you let them into this new pool when it was much more in everybody's interests to go for organisations that had experience with long‐term capital? That is in fact what Labor did. If I was to criticise our foray into this field, I would say that we overreacted to what happened in the 1980s. We put the most stringent prudential controls and responsibilities on the trustees and, as a result, the lag from receiving these funds and putting them into action in the economy has been far too long.

Even a thing like home loans, which are just the easiest thing for any financial institution to do, took eight years. And it took them three years to understand and even get interested in infrastructure bonds, even with the federal Labor Government writing special legislation giving them a half tax deal. So she is a very conservative, slow moving juggernaut. But, make no mistake, it is a juggernaut. It is a huge pool of capital that has never existed in Australia before.

We have all these economists running around saying that Australians are poor savers. What tripe! Australians are prolific savers, but they choose to do it in the form of bricks and mortar. From the day they start work they set as their savings goal buying their own home. They put aside enormous amounts of their weekly pay to pay for that house. That is great, but it does not leave any money to invest in that long list of ideas and inventions—

TALK.START.PARA: —They will need that to get into a nursing home now.

—They will need it for a nursing home later—that is dead correct. It does not leave any money to invest in that long list of Australian ideas and inventions that have gone offshore because we did not have the capital and we did not have the investment culture to back our own ideas. Overseas investors cannot get here quickly enough. If you have a good Australian idea you have to beat off the overseas investors who want to invest in it and own it.
—Then take it overseas.

—And then take it home. But here is this crowd sitting on this huge pool of capital, still trying to work out whether they should or they should not. The investment culture will develop and I think it is the most dramatic change in the structure of the Australian economy. I do not believe those opposite understand it or know the potential of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am extremely disappointed at their long‐term aversion to superannuation. Remember, Chifley started it; Menzies knocked it off. Remember, Whitlam tried to do it; Fraser knocked it off. Hawke and Keating have done it; now Howard is here, along with Costello, knocking it off, first of all discouraging high income earners with the surcharge so that they are all saying, `Why would you bother?' As they fiddle around with it more and more, the whole culture of savings through superannuation that has been created in Australia is being turned around, so that even ordinary people are now saying, `Gee, I don't want to put my money in super if governments are going to fiddle around with it.'
We are unhappy with the advent of RSAs—there is no question about that—and we are going to try and modify it. But I want to take this opportunity of putting it on the record. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to make a contribution in the Main Committee in support of the government's retirement savings accounts legislation, which is the fulfilment of another election commitment. It has been interesting to listen to Labor Party members talk, particularly over the last 12 months, on different issues and different pieces of legislation that the government has been bringing forward since the Labor Party was voted out of office, after 13 years in power, by the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to listen to the previous speaker, the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), talking about what happened during those 13 years as though someone else was in government, someone else was in charge, someone else had control of the levers. The Labor Party was in government for those 13 years. It had ample opportunity to address those things.

The previous speaker was railing against the banks. I am no great advocate of the banks either, but the Labor Party in government had plenty of opportunity to deal with some of the issues that the previous speaker raised with regard to the banks. He asked why the banks should be allowed into this sector of the economy. It is all about competition, flexibility and choice.

Interestingly, it was the Labor Party that hurtled down the path of a national competition policy to try and engender more competition in every sector of the Australian economy. This is just another part of that. That was old Labor. There has been a conversion on the road to Lismore or Adelaide or somewhere over the last three or four days with a change in the attitude of the Labor Party towards liberalisation, competition and those sorts of things. They are going in the other direction. It seems that they have completely junked the philosophy of their former leader and Prime Minister, Mr Keating.

As I said at the outset, RSAs are the fulfilment of an election commitment by the coalition. We acknowledged that there was a flaw in the superannuation system in this country where particular people in particular walks of life were making contributions of an obligatory nature into superannuation funds. They seemed to be drifting into the ether, whether they be itinerant workers or part‐time workers—they were making contributions but they were not in control of them.

We went through a process in the history of Australia where obligatory superannuation was fine, but it was under the care and control of trustees. In some cases—and I underline that—the trustees were helping themselves to fairly heavy and handy management fees. A lot of people who were not making large contributions to superannuation funds were having them seriously eroded and they were losing a lot of the value of what they were putting away. That was devaluing the former government's philosophy of having obligatory superannuation.

The coalition wanted to see some flexibility, choice and portability so that the average Australians out there—the battlers, if you like—had the opportunity to have some control over and understanding of what they were contributing to and were able to make that choice.

A point that, to my knowledge, has not been raised in this debate on the RSA legislation is that a lot of the people who will take the opportunity to put their superannuation savings into these accounts have a fair bit of ability and commonsense. They know when it is costing them too much for someone to manage their money. They know when it is a good product and when it is a bad one. They have the ability to research those things.

These people are not dummies. They are fairly smart people. They have got their lives together and they are pretty well organised. They have the ability to manage themselves and manage these accounts. We should not underestimate the ability of the majority of Australians to undertake that exercise in a fairly smart way. They do not need so‐called smart trustees to manage their affairs for them.

As I say, this product is all about flexibility and choice. RSAs provide low‐income and casual workers with an exciting new vehicle in which to invest their superannuation savings. RSAs represent the fulfilment of another coalition election promise. RSAs are something that the battlers have wanted for a long time. The Labor Party was unable to deliver on that—I think it has been raised already—and maybe that is because it did not suit its coalition partner, the ACTU, which is involved in the superannuation fund business.

RSAs are simple, low‐cost, low‐risk superannuation products which can be offered by banks, building societies, credit unions and life offices, so RSAs are not just in the domain of the banks. There are a number of highly competitive institutions that will be participating in providing this product.

BREAK.PARA: The accounts will be owned and controlled by the member and subject to the same taxation and retirement income standards as other superannuation products, including preservation. RSAs will be able to accept superannuation guarantee contributions and contributions on behalf of non‐working and low-income spouses. RSAs will be required to be capital guaranteed, that is, a guarantee that the account will not be eroded by negative investment returns. That is one of the positive elements of this.

There will be no cap on RSA balances, rather, it will be mandatory for RSA providers to advise account‐holders of alternative, balanced portfolio products offering potentially higher returns over the longer term when their account balance has reached $10,000. RSAs are about flexibility and empowering people to make informed choices about their superannuation savings. I highlight that again. The majority of people in Australia have the ability to make those informed choices and decisions for themselves. They do not need governments to do it for them.

The big winners from RSAs are average Australians, the battlers, if you like. In particular, the low cost, low risk nature of RSAs will be especially suited to people with small amounts of superannuation such as itinerant and casual workers, people wishing to amalgamate several small superannuation accounts and people nearing retirement who wish to minimise the market risk on their superannuation savings.

There was an interesting article, Mr Deputy Speaker, that appeared in The Australian towards the end of last year. It was headed, Control to shift towards retirees. I will just quote a couple of paragraphs out of this article. It was an interview with Mr Bill Peck, a partner of the law firm Phillips Fox. He said that they could shift control of the system away from employers and fund trustees towards fund members. People with RSAs will have greater ownership and control of their RSAs.

Mr Peck went on to say RSAs offer good support to the argument that where prudentially controlled institutions are concerned, a trust structure and a trustee or custodian only add to cost rather than protection. That is, in my mind, at the nub of what the government is trying to achieve here. As federal members of parliament over the years, we have received numerous representations from people that have been paying into different superannuation funds expressing their concern at the cost of the management of those funds. It comes back to the contributor. That burden is borne by the contributor. You do not mind a fair go; you do not mind paying for a service. But in a lot of cases it was, as I said earlier in my address, certainly a fairly healthy charge on behalf of some trustees that were managing those funds.
It was interesting to note in an address in Sydney on 23 August 1996, the Prime Minister indicated that RSAs will be especially significant for women. He said:
They—
the RSAs—

will be particularly beneficial for women; many of whom have intermittent periods in the work force in their early years and attached to their retirement savings account is a tax incentive for a husband or wife to contribute up to a certain level, contributions on behalf of the spouse out of the work force.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I indicated before that we believe that the Labor Party in government failed to address this very important element of superannuation, that there was a gap in the marketplace as far as superannuation was concerned. It is one of those issues that the previous Labor government failed to do enough about. It was raised on numerous occasions by the coalition in opposition over the last term of the last parliament. It was one of those issues that demonstrates why Labor is in opposition and we are in government. When we spoke about these things, we showed the Australian people that we could understand the problem that existed in this area. We showed the Australian people that we had an idea of how we could go about addressing that problem. We also showed the Australian people that we believed that they had the ability to manage their own affairs and they did not need the heavy hand of government in there doing it for them. That was a very salient point. From personal experience people appreciated that understanding, that empathy that was shown by the coalition in saying, `Yes, we understand your concerns about this. A lot of the management fees that are being deducted from your superannuation funds are too great; they are too heavy handed; they are eroding the benefit that you are likely to receive.'
The people of Australia appreciated that. As I say, it is one of our election commitments from last year that is being fulfilled in this legislation.
The Treasurer (Mr Costello) summed it up best in an answer to a question about retirement savings account in the House on 19 June last year, when he said:

Year after year the Labor government rejected the opportunity for choice and for people to open up retirement savings accounts. You were not interested in giving employees choice. You were interested in making sure that the money was controlled by the friends which controlled your government—the ACTU.
This is a government which will give people choice. It is not beholden in the way that the Labor Party was to those privileged and special interests.

I note at this point the comments that were made by the previous speaker in this debate, the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) with regard to the contributions that were made by some of the banks to the Liberal Party. I am not a member of the Liberal Party, and so I was not a beneficiary of any of those contributions. I might be wrong, but I thought from the report that was in one of the political commentaries in a magazine recently that there were also some contributions to the Labor Party from some of those banks. I might stand corrected, but I think you will find that there were.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not $10 million!
—No. I think you will find that there were.

BREAK.PARA: I will close by quoting from one of our former colleagues in our last parliament who had a great deal to do with superannuation matters and certainly with the development of this policy: the then member for Bradfield, Mr David Connolly. The parliamentary secretary's second reading speech acknowledged the contribution of the former member for Bradfield, who was one of the early architects of the coalition's RSA proposal. Speaking in the House on 10 May 1995 in a debate on the Small Superannuation Accounts Bill 1995, he said:
We believe in freedom of choice. We believe in greater competition. We believe in greater protection for contributors.
And he went on to say that he was a great supporter of more choice in superannuation. He also said in that speech:

It is not new. All the countries of the OECD—Canada, the United States, Great Britain and many others—have products such as retirement savings accounts, which have the greatest benefit of all. You empower individuals, especially people with low incomes . . .

That is what this is about. It is an acknowledgment of the ability of people in that sector of our society to manage their own affairs, to have choice, to have the flexibility of where they want to invest their retirement savings and not to have to put up with the products that are forced upon them by the heavy hand of government interfering in their private affairs.

I will close on the point that I made earlier with regard to the coalition getting through to the people of Australia the message that we understood their concerns about superannuation and that we were prepared to do something about making these products far more flexible for their use. We acknowledge the understanding, knowledge and wisdom that the average Australian has in managing his or her own affairs. The member for Burke also pointed out that, for a lot of years, people on average incomes have been investing in the family home. That is their nest egg that they have been building up: they have been investing in the family home. And that is exactly the point I make.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you'll take it away when they go into a nursing home.

—No. The point that I make is that Australians over the generations have recognised home ownership as being a very important forced means of savings, and they have always have that ability to make that decision for themselves and also to stick to the savings goal that they have had. We recognise the ability of people to manage their own affairs and, with the introduction of retirement savings accounts, we will provide the flexibility and the choice of product as far as superannuation is concerned, and we will be empowering the people to make that choice themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been interesting listening to a couple of government members talking about superannuation. I want to respond to a couple of points the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) made. First, he said the coalition had been prescient in recognising that people did not want to suffer under the heavy hand of government as far as superannuation was concerned. Let me say that I do not know that there was any government superannuation company out there in the private market where the Labor government was compelling people to save with them. I am not sure, but perhaps the minister, when he sums up, could tell us just how many private superannuation companies are seeking funds to be placed with them by workers.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it is a completely free market. As the honourable member for Bourke (Mr O'Keefe) said in his contribution, it had been a Labor Party policy. It had been a Labor Party desire to have one national fund. But historically this had been resisted and when superannuation proposals were being put through in the Hawke/Keating Labor years, as much as we would have liked to have done it, in fact, we were not going to be given the opportunity.

The other thing I wanted to comment about to the honourable member for Lyne is that I am not aware of a superannuation fund operated by the ACTU. There is none. What I am aware of is that there are industry funds which have both trade union representatives, and I assume that is what he is objecting to, as well as there being employer representatives in these funds. Mr Deputy Speaker, with your background, you may be able to correct me, but my understanding is that the ACTU has no superannuation fund that it tries to get all trade unionists' funds.

In listening to all the ranting and raving about choice and flexibility and portability and how good the coalition government is, I think that we just need to restate a few things. In 1983, 40 per cent of males had access to superannuation. In the main, they were in the public service, or they were executives in private enterprise. But ordinary workers did not. It was even worse as far as females were concerned. A miserable 24 per cent were covered by superannuation. That is an appalling record that John Howard left as Treasurer in 1983. It was something that the Labor Party was committed to change.

I often feel that, given half a chance to succeed, these superannuation reforms by Labor will be, perhaps, one of our best monuments of that period of office. But what happened to that 40 per cent? By 1996, 90 per cent of all males were covered by superannuation and, as far as women were concerned, it was even more dramatic: 24 per cent to 85 per cent. But for those people—that is, the 60 per cent of males in the population and the 76 per cent of females—there was not one iota of concern by the coalition when they were in office. Not one scintilla of concern. The coalition were happy for them not to be covered by superannuation and when they come up here with this bill, they cannot even acknowledge the progress that has been made. I think that that progress has been really great.

The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) referred to the history of superannuation in this country and, in fact, the Chifley measure that set up the national welfare fund. All working Australians were required to pay a proportion of their income into the fund. When they got their tax return, it showed the tax that they had paid and the amount they had been levied under the national welfare fund. As he rightly points out, even today, some older pensioners will come up and say to you, `This pension is not a hand‐out by the government; this is something I contributed to.'

What did the Liberals do when they got into office in the 1950s? They butchered it. Firstly, Menzies did away with the separation so that there was no distinction. It was just all shown as one form of taxation in your income tax return. Then he said that there should no longer be a separate national welfare fund; it all should go to consolidated revenue. At the end of the Menzies years there was just a shell. All it was was a bit of legislation with no money in it. That is what happened. This was a fully funded fund. If only it had been allowed to continue. If only it had not been butchered by the coalition.

I want to say a little about the RSAs. Of course, it is true that the coalition was obligated to the banks. The honourable member for Lyne, who represents a rural area, should note that these are the very same banks that were chucking out farmers hand over fist. Just recently, on This Day Tonight, we had an example—I think Pegasus was the name of the company—of `a small Australian company specialising in designing brewery apparatus and winning markets in China. An overwhelming majority of its business was in exports. It had been successful, and had built up 60 Australians in that company all using their brain power. And what happened? A bank foreclosed it.

That is the sort of organisation that the coalition government is indebted to. They are the same banks who are screwing their customers mercilessly with their fees and charges; the same banks who, if they cannot earn a billion or two billion dollars profit each and every year, think they are very unsuccessful. These are the people that the coalition government has rewarded with RSAs. They are saying, `This is competition. We have got to allow the banks into it.' The banks were already into superannuation because of their insurance cross‐ownership and operations. They had a stakehold in it but, no, they wanted these accounts.

It will be interesting to listen to the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), who represents a Victorian regional seat, explain how he is going to ask young people, if they are lucky enough to get a job when 30 per cent nationally are unemployed, how they are going to exercise their freedom of choice to have their superannuation placed in an RSA. Of course they are not. They are going to go into the fund that the employer tells them to go into. It is absolute hogwash to say that this is freedom of choice. But if they do go into an RSA, are they going to get a healthy return? Is it really going to significantly build up their superannuation entitlements? Of course it is not. You might be getting huge security out of this, but you will be getting minimal returns.

I reject this notion of RSAs. The banks—the principle beneficiaries of this legislation—have a responsibility to husband and marshall the savings of the nation. Sure, I accept that we have a savings problem. But let me quote the figures to you. In 1983, when the then Treasurer was John Howard, the amount in superannuation funds was $40 billion. In 1997, that figure is not $60 billion, not $70 billion, not $100 billion, but $350 billion. I was criticised by my colleague the member for Burke for suggesting that, by the year 2000, it would be $500 billion. He suggested I was too conservative. It would be much more.

Banks have a responsibility for marshalling the nation's savings. Have they got a really great track record in promoting Australian industry, in funding Australian research, in ensuring that Australian innovation is retained and developed in the country and exported from Australia? Of course they do not. They have a miserable record, otherwise we would not, as a government, have had to plough money into research and development programs that the current government has cut back.

When you are talking about the battlers, about Mr and Mrs Average and what they want from their superannuation funds, sure, they want their funds to be safe, to be there when they retire. That is why we have a prudential regime with superannuation companies. But they also want to have a job and they want a job for their son or daughter. If you fail to start funding Australian industry, Australian research and development, you are not going to have those jobs; they just will not be there. If you are saying, `Let it rip, it's market forces. Unemployment for young people: 30 per cent—that's not so bad; if it floats up even higher, that's just market forces,' if you are saying that the institutional infrastructure of Australia, like savings institutions, like the banks we are rewarding overwhelmingly today, have no role to play in that, then there are not going to be those jobs.

I am not asking that the majority of funds of existing superannuation funds go into developing Australian industry or Australian innovation, but I believe that some ought to. I think some ought to, consistent with trying to manage their responsibility to the people who are putting funds in there. I do not want to get into a debate about whether it should be one per cent or five per cent, but there ought to be some. When they make an annual report, let them report on how they have been doing it.

In relation to the banks, it has been a miserable history. Right through the eighties when we implemented banking deregulation, they shovelled money at the top end of town like it was going out of fashion. When the proverbial hit the fan, it was not the top end of town that really paid; it was small business, medium sized business and people with longstanding overdrafts and credit facilities. All of a sudden, with no deterioration in their business, they were called up. Many of them went out of business.

The banks did not care. They had a policy of recovering a certain percentage of money. They did not care if they bankrupted people. They got a percentage of what the business was worth. They just went out and did it. I would be interested in hearing from the member for Bendigo what the changes are. Is this not happening any more in Bendigo? I can tell him that it still happens in my electorate. As I said, I refer to the This Day Tonight program. We are rewarding the same people who had—and, frankly, still have—such a cavalier attitude by putting workers' money in their accounts. We are boosting their amount of savings.

I suppose this may be a little pedantic but, given this nourished, long held view of the coalition of the importance of retirement savings accounts, I am surprised that there is not one word of how much money is going to go in there. There is not one prediction about how popular this will be. I have read the second reading speech by the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles), and I could not find one word about it.

Could the person who will sum up this debate tell the people of Australia what the foregone returns will be by people who have put their money in RSAs? For example, if people invest $100 million in RSAs, what will they be earning compared with other industry funds? What will be the difference? What will be the foregone income of these people? If this legislation is passed and if someone signed up for it tomorrow, what will it mean over their working life? The member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) made a few remarks that I want to respond to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well informed remarks if I remember.
—You obviously were not watching him because I know you were not here. You might revise that if you saw the tape.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for North Sydney was emphasising the issue of choice. I do not mind choice. What he was saying, as was the member for Lyne, was that the superannuation of itinerant workers and people with small amounts of money was being eaten away by management fees. That was true when the scheme was first introduced. I think it was one of those unintended consequences. What was really unfortunate was that there was no discussion of our legislative amendments which enabled people with amounts of $1,000 to have no management fees attracted to them whatsoever.

Again, if this is going to benefit the workers it would have been nice in 1983 if the coalition had stood up for the 60 per cent of males or the 76 per cent of females who did not have superannuation. We ought to be proud that we have increased the coverage from 40 per cent to 90 per cent for males and from 24 per cent to 85 per cent for females.

A degree of compulsion is always needed in terms of savings. The member for Lyne acknowledged that home ownership is most people's way of compulsory saving. You can run some numbers through and show that it is not as cost effective or beneficial as some other forms of saving, but I do not deprecate people—and I am certainly in that boat—who try to save significantly through home ownership.

It is the same with superannuation. We could say to the people of Australia, `You have complete freedom of choice. You can either pocket what you would get in superannuation or you can put it in a fund.' However, if people are raising a family, have young children, and have all sorts of expenses to contemplate, they will never have sufficient money to save, but they will manage on the money they get. That is why it is important that there is an element of compulsion in superannuation.

Home ownership is great, but it is not going to be sufficient to provide for retirement. Most people, even pensioners, that I have spoken to would like to see their children or their grandchildren in a much healthier retirement situation than they enjoy, although the pension would always be the safety net for them.

We have a national savings problem. We ought to encourage all forms of saving, including encouraging people to save for their retirement via superannuation. As the member for Burke has indicated, the opposition, whilst moving an amendment to this later, as I understand it, is not going to hold up this package of legislation.

Coalition members talk about choice and flexibility. The real choice they are getting with RSAs is to reward the banks. If the people of Australia think the banks need to be rewarded for their efforts through the 1980s and 1990s, for their profits, or for the way they are increasing their fees and charges on the accounts of punters or even small business, then fair enough. However, I happen to disagree with that perspective very strongly.

The real choice people will be getting when they get an RSA is to get a much smaller income. There will be freedom of choice, flexibility and portability, but all on a journey to a much lower return than they would get if they were exercising some other form of superannuation saving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1996 and cognate bills because this is important legislation. It is another election promise fulfilled by the Howard government. The retirement savings accounts are quite different from what the member for Chifley (Mr Price) just elucidated in this chamber. I hope the honourable member will stay here for a little while because I want to respond to some of his comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Retirement investments take a variety of forms. If I were to look around this chamber at the provision that members have made for the day when they leave the work force, I would find that every one of the strategies would be totally different. It takes many forms. Retirement savings accounts are yet another form of investment, but this is a form of investment in which people will have a choice. They will have the choice to decide how their retirement income will be put into reserve for the day when they leave the work force.

I want to run through some of the forms that people choose for their retirement. In fact, when people start saving for their retirement, they often have a range of investments which they put aside for their future. It may be domestic property; it may be their own home and many Australians have the great Australian dream of owning their own home. That quite obviously has been a form of retirement saving to either buy or build a home for their retirement so that they are in fact secure and have shelter for the future for themselves and their spouse and members of their family when they are growing up.

That is just one method of retirement savings, and superannuation, of course, is another. But that is a choice that should and could be chosen by anyone who decides that that is their best investment. They have the opportunity to make that choice. Other avenues of property investment could be commercial or industrial investment. Some people choose to in fact invest in other forms of real estate, whether it be land or property in buildings. There is also the Australian share market and investing in Australian companies so that the future of Australia in fact does expand and they take a small slice of equity in an Australian company which promotes jobs and in fact reinvests money back into Australia and provides the opportunity for people to also have additional retirement funds.

The investment funds of a number of companies are available to investors. They can go in with a small entry contribution and they can, over a period of their working life, contribute to investment funds. To hear the member for Chifley in his speech you would think that there is only one acceptable form of retirement investment, and that is superannuation. There are many forms and people will exercise those choices and the idea of saying to people that you must contribute to a superannuation form, it is compulsory for you to contribute to a superannuation investment, is the way the Australian Labor Party operates. They say that we know best, but I can tell you that they did not know best.

I just want to take you back to the period when Labor thought that they knew all the answers. You had to go into superannuation and you had to do certain things. They thought they knew how to run this economy. When interest rates went from 8 per cent to 23 per cent in the recession we had to have that demonstrated the error of the ways of the Australian Labor Party. They did not know best. They did not know how to manage other people's money. What they did in fact was drive many thousands of people in Australia out of their homes. They lost their homes during the recession we had to have and those homes were part of their retirement and superannuation funds, the retirement for their life after they have left the work force.
