Thousands of people in Australia during that period lost their homes because the Australian Labor Party thought they knew best. They still think it. They think that they know best and they are saying to you that you must have compulsory superannuation. You cannot exercise any other choice in your retirement savings.

What we are offering for people is a whole range of opportunities for their retirement when they leave the work force and I am afraid for the Labor Party to still be persisting with this idea that there has to be compulsory savings. You only have to look back at the track record of the previous government. I think the member for Chifley was berating the banks for their performance during 13 years of Labor Government. They were remarkably silent during that 13 years of office. If they felt there was something wrong, it certainly did not show in their actions and after all of that time the Labor Party took very little action if they thought there was anything so drastically wrong with what the banks were doing.

I think there have been problems with superannuation, and particularly for people running small balances in superannuation funds. The three areas of concern for compulsory superannuation were, firstly, the lack of choice, secondly, the small balances and, thirdly, the proliferation of small accounts that people had. We are offering them an opportunity to get away from compulsory superannuation by investing in retirement savings accounts which will be offered by financial institutions. I will go through some of those financial institutions in a moment.

To hear the honourable member for Chifley, you would think that the banks were the only ones offering these retirement savings accounts. An RSA institution can be a bank, a building society, a credit union, a life insurance company or a prescribed financial institution that has approval. It certainly opens up the range of organisations offering retirement savings accounts.

Every member of this House, this parliament, would have had complaints from people with a part‐time job who were employed in the work force for a few hours a week and who were compelled to go into the superannuation guarantee contributions under the Labor government's legislation, the superannuation guarantee contributions legislation. When that legislation was introduced, there were no means of protecting small balances in superannuation sums arising from those compulsory contributions. People found that, after a very short time, any contributions that had been deducted from their earnings as a part‐time worker were eroded by fees and charges. In fact, some balances went into the negative and they ended up owing the superannuation fund.

The charges that were imposed by some of the superannuation funds resulted in many people being disillusioned with superannuation. They could see their contributions not only being reduced but going into the red. The retirement savings accounts offer a capital guarantee. That will have a lot of benefits, and not only for people who want to choose different means for handling their retirement money. The thing that has come to our notice through the member for Chifley, and other members of the former government, is the Labor Party's paranoia about compulsory superannuation payments.

Compulsory superannuation required that a certain percentage of an employee's salary be contributed to superannuation and, of course, people had no choice. They were forced to go into this but people like the freedom of being able to exercise their choice and to have a range of retirement benefits and to not necessarily have all of their retirement package invested in superannuation.

We have seen in Australia a number of people taking substantial sums out of their superannuation funds on their retirement. They may have been people who were almost ready to retire but who had a part‐time job to keep them going for a period and so they looked around for suitable investments for their funds. During the horrible period of the 1980s and early 1990s, under Labor, some of those investments that superannuants made were fairly risky and a lot of people lost their money.

That was an area then that caused a great deal of trauma for a number of people. Retirement savings accounts open up a whole new area for people who are approaching retirement age. Those who are nearing retirement who wish to perhaps find a safe place to park their retirement money or their superannuation prior to actually getting out of the work force full time could park their money in an RSA prior to retirement and it would be capital guaranteed. It would be of a low risk nature and the RSAs should be more attractive to people under those circumstances.

We heard the contribution by members on the other side of the chamber, particularly the member for Chifley. I am disappointed that he did not stay for a little while. Maybe he had some commitments. I think the important thing is to remember that, in all of the investment plans of every person in society, they will all choose different methods of approaching their retirement and how they will take care of their life after they leave the work force. To hinge all of your hopes and aspirations purely and simply onto superannuation, for a lot of people is not necessarily an option. In fact they may wish to secure, as I indicated earlier, other investments in a whole range of products that might give them greater security than compulsory superannuation.

That is what the Retirement Savings Account Bill does offer to people. There is even the opportunity for people with RSA balances, when they reach a limit of $10,000, to be offered a full range of other potential products. That is part of this legislation. They do have flexibility within that retirement savings account whereby they can explore a whole range of other options once it reaches the $10,000 balance. They can look at other investments.

I think back to the time when I had many representations from people who were working part time in the work force and doing a whole range of casual jobs. At the end of the financial year, when checking on their balance in their compulsory superannuation, they found it to be absolutely nil. They had a nil balance in their account. They paid in all of this money and at the end of it all there was nothing there. It particularly affected women in the work force who, on many occasions, were working part time. They found at the end of a period of 12 months part-time work in the work force that in fact they had a nil balance in that account.
Retirement savings accounts will provide a capital guaranteed fund, lower fees and another option on retirement for people who are leaving the work force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this bill is worth supporting. It adds another string to the bow. But to suggest this is of any real significance really is an exercise in self delusion. As everyone knows, self delusion is the greatest treason.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned at the lack of political memory. I heard the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) talking about those terrible years of the 1980s and early 1990s. I was in parliament in the years when Malcolm Fraser and John Howard had driven interest rates equally high, when there were bank foreclosures of equal numbers and where they had managed to get inflation up at enormous rates as well. What it comes down to is frankly no difference between the performance of either party. They have both got it wrong.

I recall some rather churlish remarks made by the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) when he was moving an adjournment. He commented that this was the way the Liberal Party was rewarding the banks, and there is an element of the Liberal Party rewarding the banks. However, it is quite clear that the superannuation brought in by the Dawkins-Keating government—Dawkins being the Treasurer—was Labor's way of rewarding insurance companies and of trying to set them off against the banks.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the unions.
—I do not need your contribution, I find it facile.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that superannuation is not going to be the answer. If you compound inflation at about 6 per cent over the life of most of the superannuants, they will probably have enough money to buy a new Holden Commodore on their retirement. This brings me to what the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) was talking about, other alternatives. One of the great alternatives talked about is the Singapore model. Unfortunately, the Singapore model would not apply in Australia; it could not apply, because we do not have the social cohesion that Singapore has with its monocultural society. In Singapore if you are not Chinese you do not matter. Where you have that enormous social cohesion it works very well.

The Singapore model is modelled on the British model, which does work well, but these are not superannuation funds, they are funded pension funds, as Chifley's scheme was. It was not a superannuation fund, it was a funded pension fund. The situation with the funded pension funds is that they are much easier to administer. Administration costs are much lower because it is done through taxation.

I believe that the British scheme has worked very well for Britain, and even Margaret Thatcher did not touch it because it was far and away the biggest contributor to innovation in British industry. Nobody else was funding it. Certainly, the banks in Britain have a history of not funding industry. It was the funded pension funds that were funding all that innovation, as happens in Singapore. Their fund has been a great funder of innovation.

That has not occurred in Australia. We have $350 billion in funds we are now told by the member for Chifley (Mr Price). It is not a big deal if you look at what they actually do with it because I do not see any evidence that any of the superannuation funds are contributing to the development of Australian industry. They are, by and large, chasing short-term gains with short-term investments. This is why the member for Bendigo correctly said that many of the funds had negative returns. Some people ended up with less money than they had contributed because the funds made some very silly short-term investments.

What is being offered here is a retirement savings account which is capital guaranteed. I believe a lot of people out there, hearing us talk about this, will believe that their money is absolutely safe, that their money cannot be lost. Of course, that is not true. There is nothing in this legislation that stops an institution going broke and if it goes broke people will be paid a very small amount. In fact, they may not get anything back at all. They could still lose their money but at least they have a better chance than with the present superannuation funds.

I want to dwell on what you could do if you had a situation where people just compounded their interest in the bank. Where there were no bank charges—or very low bank charges as exists in Japan and as used to exist here—and where there was low inflation, this was a foolproof method. It offered all the benefits of the retirement savings account. It gave people maximum flexibility and was less risky because the banks are governed by all sorts of prudential requirements. It was unlikely, but not impossible, that they would go broke. Certainly, administration costs would be much lower, and it is something that could be looked at in Australia. If we had a situation where a bank was prepared to take money on a compound interest basis and not charge exorbitant charges, people could look at a savings bank.

People do need an incentive to save because there are always requirements for money, particularly when you are raising a family. To make those savings tax free would be one way of giving an incentive. But to run any institution like that you would need a government owned bank—and that is not likely to happen, with the urban centralist socialist government of Paul Keating having sold the only bank that we owned and the present urban centralist government of John Howard not being likely to reverse that decision. Those options have been closed off to us and that is a great shame, because it would have provided a source of funding which could have gone to lending for Australian industry development, which is not adequately funded now.

You only have to go out and talk to people, particularly small businesses, to find out they simply cannot get the funds for development. I might add that we have seen a situation recently in the ACT where the government was approached by a small business association to fund a youth employment project. I think it was a very good project, but they were not interested because they said it was a Commonwealth responsibility and they did not have the money for it.

But they seem to have found the money lend to an investor—in fact, apparently to give to an investor—to build a church in which to marry Japanese couples, the idea being that we are going to make a fortune by flying these people into Australia and marrying them here. It is an absolute nonsense concept. They will not spend much money here, if they come at all. If there was a great return on it, the Japanese would have done it long ago. It is an indictment for the ACT government that they are prepared to fund that, but not to fund anything for youth employment. That is just one example of the sort of nonsense you get when we should be talking about investment in providing a future for ourselves.

One of the great things that does provide for people's future is a job. If you have a job, you can make provision; if you have not got a job, it is very hard to get provision of any sort. I was rather amused to hear Gough Whitlam still taking credit for his 25 per cent tariff cut across the board. In the late 1960s and early 1970s there were a lot of British high‐tech companies coming to Australia and establishing the sorts of industries we needed for the future. What Whitlam did was to cut the ground from under their feet and send them skittling back to Britain. We never did get those high‐tech industries which, if we had got them at that time, would have made things much better for us now. Even all these years later, Whitlam has never seen the light and never recognised the damage that he did.

BREAK.PARA: Sadly, Whitlam's action was applauded by the then opposition. I have no doubt they would have done the same. That brings me back to a theme I have been hammering in this parliament recently: in reality, there is no difference between those who sit on the government side of the House and the opposition; they are simply factions of the one party. That is why, Mr Deputy Speaker, you are finding increasing acrimony and personal attacks on individuals. It is because there is no difference in substance in what they are promoting and they are reduced to attacking each other. It is a very sad state for the development of Australia.

It must be made clear—and the government should go to some pains to make it clear to people—that the capital guarantee does not mean that the investment cannot go bad. I recall the heady days in the 1980s when Rothwells had an absolute top credit rating bestowed on it by all the credit rating people around the world. It was a guaranteed investment which local government could invest in—and many foolishly did. The real situation was that the Bourke government, on a bank holiday weekend in September 1988, was faced with the knowledge that, if they did not bail out Rothwells, its doors would not open on the Tuesday and the government would be faced with significant costs which would probably have amounted to $150 million. Part of that figure was because Catholic education had all its money invested in Rothwells and the government, which had an obligation to provide education, would have had to bail out Catholic education.

Most conservative country shires had money invested in Rothwells because it was paying two per cent over the regular rate, which in itself should have been a warning. Bodies like the Activ Foundation had money in Rothwells. Everyone feels obligated to help spastics, so the foundation would have been bailed out. Many others would have come out of the woodwork, and would also have been bailed out. On the other hand, if the government gave the guarantee, they were assured by the auditor and by people who were supposed to know a lot about cash flow that it was simply a cash flow crisis and that Rothwells was very sound.

Subsequently, we found out that in 1987 Rothwells went broke, but in 1987 it declared a large dividend. In 1988 it was still broke and it declared a larger dividend, but the government would have been the last to know. By stepping in there, the government stopped an additional run on the stock exchange. It held up the fund until all the small investors got their money out, and it probably saved about 10,000 jobs. Companies borrowing money from Rothwells were able to restructure their affairs and put their money elsewhere. When history is accurately recorded, it will be seen that the government of the day in Western Australia did a good job.

I add that, subsequently, it has been assessed by senior, and obviously knowledgeable, academics that the Burke government left an economic situation in Western Australia second only to that in Queensland, where Bjelke‐Petersen had left the finances of every government department in an absolutely tip‐top state. In fact, he had every hollow log stuffed with money. That was the largesse that the subsequent Labor government was able to access, and it made a lot of good propaganda for itself in so doing.

I support this bill. It is another option. I think it provides many useful functions. Parking of superannuation pay‐offs is clearly one of them. It also enables people who are only part‐time participants, people who have very small contributions, to participate. However, I do not believe it is going to be the answer to the savings this country needs.

It is quite clear that while every member agrees that we need some sort of compulsion for people to invest in superannuation, some sort of compulsion is also required to get the superannuation funds to invest in Australia. There is absolutely no evidence that they are prepared to do this of their own free will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the three bills that are being considered tonight—the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill, the Retirement Savings (Consequential Amendments) Bill and the Retirement Savings Accounts Supervisory Levy Bill. I was heartened to hear some of the views of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). This legislation is not a panacea, but it is a good start to broadening our superannuation base, particularly for low‐income earners, itinerant workers, women casual workers and part‐time workers.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is designed to give more certainty to the federal government's retirement incomes policy, most importantly for those people who are approaching retirement. It is part of one of many elements that goes to developing a proper plan for superannuation and income retirement. At the end of the day, it is to provide choice, adequate competition, greater scope and portability for those people who choose to put their money into RSA type accounts.

When looking at the history of superannuation, it is necessary to look as well at the history of the labour market and how there have been variations in the patterns of saving and spending for retirement. In July 1992, when the Labor government introduced the superannuation guarantee charge, it started with the best intentions. At that time the levy was placed at three per cent.

It was unfortunate that, during the eighties when they took away the tax deductibility status for superannuation, the onus was almost exclusively on the employer, as there were numerous wage trade‐offs during the Accord which built in superannuation. The levy was at three per cent in 1992; it is now at seven per cent. The target is nine per cent by 2003‐04 of actual contributions made.

I suppose the whole reason for the retirement policy that the previous government put in place and which we are continuing is the ageing demographics of the population. Having a pension system is not sufficient enough to take up the scope of the Commonwealth budget. That is why we are trying to encourage people to plan for their retirement. In this case, it is being legislated for.

During that time, as is happening now, there was a superannuation contribution tax of 15 per cent. There was a tax on the trustees running those superannuation funds of 15 per cent. There is also this government's change to income earners over $70,000, which amounts to an additional charge of 15 per cent.

The whole reason this was clearly identified was that Dr FitzGerald inquired into the level of savings in this country. One of the problems we have as compared with other Western developed countries is that we have very low levels of savings. There certainly is an encouragement that, if you are going to spend, spend on debt, because generally speaking it is a deduction. There is also a proliferation of negative gearing. No wonder we have very low savings.

During the eighties and the nineties there has been a major shift of financial capital from the banks to superannuation. That has been geared principally because of the compulsory superannuation guarantee charge. Today $248 million is in super funds. The vast majority of real money is now sitting in superannuation accounts. Last year there was a growth rate of 8.9 per cent, so it is accelerating. For the year 2001, we are looking at a capital base within our superannuation of $348 billion. So it is a big chunk of money.

BREAK.PARA: Unfortunately, many life insurance companies and superannuation funds are restricted in their charter when it comes to lending. They are not lending for small business; they are not lending for capital expansion; they are investing in liquid assets, be that in the stock market, in property or overseas. I believe these RSAs will provide another string in the bow for banks which will be able to compete in this market. More importantly, capital going into RSAs in banks will be on balance sheets and will be used for future lending facilities.

Let us look at the changing work force. The reason we need another avenue is that there is an increasing amount of casual work and part‐time work. People no longer have one job in their life time. The statistics show that there will be four career changes in an average working career of someone now entering the work force.
Mr Sawford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That statistic has been around for a number of years under your government. What is needed is portability because, when people move from one career to a different career, they have to have a superannuation scheme that goes with them. That is why I think the RSA scheme is very good.

BREAK.PARA: Let us look at the latest ABS statistics. Over the December quarter, there was an increase in jobs. The principal amount of those jobs created—and this is not the best outcome—is in part‐time and casual work. All of those people need portability in their superannuation. As mentioned before, a lot of these people have small superannuation accounts with many different providers because of the many different jobs that they have had.

I have also mentioned that we have seen a shift in capital within the financial institutions. Capital is going from the banks to superannuation funds. We are seeing a blurring in financial markets. For example, Colonial, which was a super fund, took over the State Bank. There is a blurring there. We are seeing a demutualisation with National Mutual. No doubt we will see a demutualisation, with shareholder approval, of AMP. We have seen the merger of a bank with an insurance company: the Queensland Bank with Metway and Suncorp in Queensland. Financial institutions are evolving to the deregulated market place. Therefore, it is necessary to provide adequate products for Australians to access for their super.

What is this about, this retirement savings account? It is a vehicle whereby people can invest in a portable superannuation which does not have a trust structure. In the past, or currently if you are with a life company or a super company, it had to be within a trust structure. This obviously is going to provide a vehicle where it will be capital guaranteed, where it will be portable, where it will be owned by the members and where there are still preservation rights. It is particularly important, as I mentioned before, for people who are low income workers with spouses. At a time when we are having a lot of marriage breakdowns, up to 40 per cent, when those relationships break up there should be some avenue for the spouse, or whatever the partner is, to have some type of superannuation.

With this particular policy, there is one area which has not been raised tonight which I think is very prudent. When the bill is passed, the new arrangements under superannuation guarantee will mean that a single income family will be able to direct some of their superannuation, up to an 18 per cent rebate or equivalent of $3,000 per spouse, to their spouse if they have got an income level under $10,800. What it is doing is providing a nest egg for that other partner. So, if there is a break‐up in a relationship, at least that person has something.

The other thing that is very positive in this is that it is a low cost product; it does not cost a lot. As many members have mentioned before, during the 1980s and during the 1990s a lot of the superannuation contributions made were eaten up by management fees, by transaction fees, not to mention bank charges, where their actual returns were negative. When you look at the actual returns in 1993‐94 and 1994‐95, they did not even perform to an indexed fund. It is only in the last couple of years that we have actually seen an increase in superannuation.

It is a low risk product. As has been mentioned, it is capital guaranteed. When a lot of people put their funds in what they thought were guaranteed funds during the 1980s, they lost a lot of money. There are no fees, or very limited fees. If the amount does drop under $1,000—there is about $400 million in funds now which have very small amounts—there is a guarantee that the actual amount contributed will not fall below that starting point through accumulation of fees or charges. I think that is very positive, because a lot of people have lost faith in superannuation.

I might add, and it is not unique to this government, that I think it is terribly important that we maintain stability within superannuation so that we do not see all these countless changes, because it just takes away the incentive and it makes it very difficult for people to plan for their retirement, which in most cases is the most important part of their lives.

The other thing is that it is going to provide a one‐stop shop. I know it is a bit of a buzz word used these days but, if you are going into a financial institution or you are going into a bank, you will also be able to have some of your super there as well as your own deposit system. Likewise, you will be able to maintain that arrangement now with current life companies or superannuation companies. As I mentioned, the big plus, though, is for people on low incomes, for spouses, for itinerant workers, for people who are not wealthy, to have this portability. It should be supported by the opposition.

How is it going to be regulated? One of the problems in the 1980s, when we had the deregulation juggernaut that sort of smashed through the door when we floated the dollar, was that there was a wildcat ride. Of course, we had the huge increase in interest rates, we had the boom‐bust of the share market, and part of this was because there were no prudential controls put into place to monitor the excesses of the 1980s. That is why it is very important, if you are going to introduce new financial legislation, to make sure you have prudential controls.

The other area which has been thought out well is the functional supervisory controls for this RSA account. The prudential framework has existed since 1957, when the Banking Act was brought down under the auspices of the Reserve Bank. That has obviously been to regulate the major banks, the major deposit base and the lending institutions. Then later on we had the build‐up of building societies and credit unions. They basically came under state supervision. Then we have had the big juggernauts which are the old life insurance companies, the most notable being AMP, Bankers Trust and MLC, just to name a few. Those particular areas will be covered, not by a prudential framework, because they cannot, but, in addition, by the ISC, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, which will supervise those statutory funds.

The other area, too, is what happens when you develop these funds and I reach retirement age? How am I going to access them? It is important that people understand that if they are going to go into an RSA, if it is with a bank, a credit union or a building society, they cannot just take funds out like a pension or annuity because such things are not provided. They are not provided because those institutions do not have what is called `mortality risk'. They are not in the business of providing ongoing payment. So, if you go to a bank or one of those institutions, it is either going to have to be an allocated pension or a lump sum. If you are with a life insurance company, it will remain as a pension or an annuity.

That is a positive element. In conclusion, it is all about offering more flexibility and better returns for those people who cannot afford more complicated or better financial advice with superannuation funds. It offers a capital guarantee. It is not going to provide incredible returns but at the moment the problem is that there is a real desire by financial institutions to race into the top quartile of performances where they have to take on greater risk to get the greater reward. They take on greater risk and, as history has proven time and time again, the potential for down years is significant. My concern, particularly with what is now quite a heated stock market, is that we could well see some other calamities happening in the next couple of years, particularly with some of those life companies.

The other thing with this is that there is a recognition that the work force is changing. We have not all got security of tenure now. We have not got full‐time jobs. People are changing; they are going to have to change, and they need that portability. The whole population is getting older. Like most western democracies, we need to have a proper savings and retirement plan. That is what this particular scheme does. I believe that it is a worthy addition to our retirement incomes policy. It is an election promise fulfilled and it should have the bipartisan support of this parliament because it is a good thing. It is also going to start to reduce some of the monopoly of capital that is heavily concentrated now in super funds. As I mentioned before, most of those super funds do not have the provision to lend to the small businesses because of their restrictions. If you have part of superannuation with the bank, you can start to build up that capital base so that they can be back in the business of lending as they should be, not just to the home mortgage market, but to small businesses at competitive rates. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 February 1996, Mr Don Mercer, Chief Executive Officer of the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, addressed a meeting of the Australian Superannuation Funds Association, ASFA. Mr Mercer was arguing the case that banks should be allowed to enter the superannuation market on two grounds, those being: improving the levels of national savings; and on the basis of non‐discrimination against the banks. He observed:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems surprising that, in an era when government policies have consciously sought to expand the range of choice available to individuals in other fields . . . the government has sponsored such a dramatic narrowing in the range of choice available to individuals as to the institutions with which they save.

The Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1996 and the two associated bills being debated cognately are about the widening of consumer choice and improving the level of competition within the superannuation sector.

This bill allows for banks, life insurance companies, credit unions and building societies to offer their customers an alternative to superannuation, in providing for themselves in retirement. In 1986, the then Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, sold the superannuation guarantee charge to the public as the answer to Australia's national savings problems.

I suggested in this place in September 1995 that that scheme could not guarantee increased national savings. Rather, I submitted then that superannuation, as it was constituted, would become a mere substitute for other forms of domestic savings.
Mr Mercer in his address to ASFA, some 12 months ago, confirmed my opinion when he said:

BREAK.PARA: Since 1986 when award superannuation began to be extended through the work force, the household savings ratio has actually declined from around seven per cent to an average of 3.3 per cent in the 1994‐95 financial year, and to 3.6 per cent in the September quarter 1995.
He continued by saying:
The household savings ratio has actually dropped by about 1.5 percentage points since the superannuation guarantee scheme formally commenced in the September quarter 1992.
Australians have shown themselves to be poor savers. One Australian journalist went so far as to describe Australia as a nation of financial delinquents.
The IPA Review in edition number 49/2 1996 summed this up very succinctly. It recorded that as a result of Australia's appalling record:
We need to import capital, equivalent to five per cent of GDP, just to provide the investment necessary to manage the lacklustre growth of the past decade or so.

Clearly, the policies of past governments have not been successful in reversing the trend of diminishing household savings. As a result, the current generation of fully employed Australians is being asked to pay for the retirement of two generations. This is unsustainable in the long term.

The financial impact statement accompanying the bill and in the explanatory memorandum suggest that the introduction of RSAs will have a negligible impact on revenue in the short term. However, if the RSA/superannuation mix does not lead to an increase in national savings, the impact on future revenue will be much more substantial, of course.

An analysis of the superannuation market by MJR Consultants revealed that as at March 1996 the public sector held between $80 billion and $100 billion in unfunded liability, most of which is a liability of the federal government. This figure will continue to burgeon and will place a massive drain on future government revenue. It is yet another reason to support the introduction of alternative savings schemes paid for in full by individuals.

The Australian Retirement Income Stream Association, ARISA, has argued that there is a lack of integration between our retirement income and social security policy. So while the government should be commended on its initiative on retirement savings accounts, the RSAs, it should be remembered that the introduction of RSAs alone will not solve the problems that have arisen because of this lack of integration.

The Weekend Australian pointed out on 3 August 1997 that without an interconnection between social security and the superannuation systems the compulsory savings regime will continue to have little impact in reducing the reliance on a taxpayer funded retirement. Many argue that means testing acts as a disincentive to savings by allowing individuals to access their superannuation contributions at age 55 and then claim the age pension at a later date.

The ARISA asserts that if the government fails to reintegrate the social security and retirement income policies, the age pension and other related costs will continue to escalate and place pressure on future budgets. It has become apparent that the emphasis on increasing national savings through superannuation, to the exclusion of all other forms of savings, is not producing the goods that Mr Keating had fallaciously claimed.

Mr Michael J. Rice, the Managing Director of MJR Consultants, has said that, while consumers are starting to accept that superannuation is a part of their overall pay, they want a greater say in its management. RSAs will offer an alternative investment option for those who are not convinced of the benefits of superannuation but who are not great risk takers. RSAs should also appeal to those who are not likely to benefit in full from superannuation.

The retirement savings accounts will remain with the owners, regardless of for whom, or when, they choose to work. This will be of particular benefit to many women, and casual and part‐time workers. As Mr Mercer went on to outline in his address to ASFA:
The current exclusive emphasis on superannuation imposes a nexus between employment and access to the preferential tax treatment which is exclusively enjoyed by superannuation.
Remember that he said that back in 1996. He also commented:
This in turn disadvantages women, and others whose labour market participation differs from those for whom superannuation schemes were originally intended.

There is a provision in the legislation for the transfer of funds out of retirement savings accounts at any time. This flexibility will advantage those who require a greater accessibility to their funds than is accommodated under superannuation arrangements as presently constituted.

The flip side of this increased flexibility is that RSAs will, in all probability, yield lower returns than most superannuation funds. But I believe the benefits of the proposed RSAs outweigh the prospect of lower returns for some who select that particular alternative as an act of free choice. An individual can decide to opt for a superannuation plan that cannot be accessed for years to come but that will produce, of course, a higher return. Alternatively, they can choose to open an RSA, knowing that the funds are available for limited use if required, and that they will face lower fees, but that the RSA is low yielding.

MLC Business and Trustee Superannuation suggested in their presentation at the 1996 superannuation summit that RSAs and superannuation will end up working in tandem with each other, and that is a most likely outcome. They suggested then that existing fund managers may be happy for the banks to take on their small account balance members, but they will try to recapture these accounts once they have started to grow. The National Commission of Audit has said:

Urgent action is needed to moderate community expectations of government assistance, increase incentives for self reliance in old age and more equitably share the cost of age‐related services funded by government.
It is to be hoped that the introduction of retirement savings accounts will see an increase in the number of people taking full responsibility for their own retirements.

Clause 15 in the explanatory memorandum outlines that an RSA must be maintained for one or more `primary purposes'. Examples of a primary purpose include retirement, attainment of the prescribed age and, heaven forbid, death—which is inevitable. In the latter case, the benefit is paid to the legal personal representative and/or the holder's dependants. That is a most important inclusion in the bill. It makes clear that, while an individual can access a portion of the funds for ancillary purposes, an RSA is to be preserved essentially for retirement income purposes.

The coalition is right to make this provision. It is right to remind all Australians that a fully government funded old age pension will be reserved only for those in real need. In January of this year the Financial Review reported the results of the latest RetireInvest survey of high income earners. It found that `while respondents expressed a desire for security and lifestyle when retired, this was not a strong impetus for goal setting.' It appears that the message about self‐funded retirement has just not been getting through.

It is fair to suggest that RSAs will contribute to an increase in savings for retirement purposes by offering tax incentives to those outside the work force or to those who have interrupted working lives. However, the coalition needs to be reminded against viewing RSAs through rose‐coloured glasses. Consistent low levels of national savings have proven to be a millstone around the neck of recent Australian governments. This initiative is unlikely to have any significant impact on savings until the bigger issue of our taxation system is reviewed. I repeat what I and many others have asserted in this place and elsewhere in the past: the current tax arrangements are overly complex, expensive and onerous to comply with. They amount to a very substantial set of disincentives to voluntary savings.

The opening up of the superannuation industry to a greater number of players is not going to see a quick fix to our national savings problem. Until the government embraces a thorough overhaul of the tax regime, initiatives like this one will meet with only limited success. The government has described RSAs as being simple, low cost, and low risk. They will be capital guaranteed and will be protected against any downward adjustment to the value of investments, ostensibly underwriting individual accounts or by negative investment returns.

However, a number of senior industry professionals have expressed concern over the decision to allow awards and workplace agreements to offer consumers a choice of up to five funds. They perceive that this will be expensive and difficult to manage. They also suggest that this arrangement is inappropriate for members who will gravitate towards risk free but poorly performing investments, and that this needs to be addressed if the concept of the RSA is to be successful.

The coalition's decision to allow banks and other financial institutions to compete with the superannuation industry participants could have a positive impact on small business. As Mr Mercer, in his ASFA address postulated:
Life offices and superannuation funds typically invest upwards of 70 per cent of their assets in the securities of governments and medium‐large corporations.
He went on:
On average, less than 9 per cent of life offices' and superannuation funds' financial assets are held as wholesale deposits in the banking system.
Mr Mercer predicted that it is unlikely that superannuation funds will develop either the expertise or the infrastructure that is necessary to support lending to small business in the short term.

Nor am I suggesting that the introduction of RSAs will solve the plethora of challenges facing the small business community. They simply will not. Every Yellow Pages small business index produced since August 1996 shows that this sector continues to trade under recession‐like conditions, despite the fact that the economy is on track for solid growth of something like 3.5 per cent during 1996‐97. However, banks remain the major creditors to small businesses. The introduction of RSAs may, therefore, well see an increase in the availability of finance for small businesses.

If the government delivers on its election promise of reducing the compliance burden for small business by 50 per cent, and if it comes up with meaningful industrial relations reform, one could expect the improved availability of finance to be of real benefit to small businesses. The spill‐over effect of that, of course, would be on the wider economy and it would be significant indeed.

The introduction of retirement savings accounts is a sensible initiative, but it will not see the end of the expectation that many Australians have of fully funded government pensions. The government's aged care policy makes it clear that those who can afford to provide for their care in the nursing home will be expected to do so. The coalition needs to be equally emphatic in developing policy that promotes self‐funded retirement. It is fair and reasonable to expect that people remain financially independent for as long as possible. By opening up the superannuation market, the government has made a feasible step down that path.

RSAs will encourage greater freedom of choice as well as increased competition between funds. This proposed facility seeks to improve equity for low-income earners and allow those not in the conventional work force to access a retirement savings fund. Most analysts agree that the introduction of RSAs will see casualties both in the existing superannuation industry and in some of the new RSA providers. But most admit that increased competition will result in initiative designed to reduce costs as well as the introduction of new services and should therefore be supported.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that a complaint was lodged in February with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) concerning the ramping of Cambridge Gulf Exploration shares; if so, (a) was the complaint lodged by Cambridge Gulf Exploration in the interests of its shareholders and (b) were persons associated with Country Natwest, Messrs Thomas, Newton and Pettorino, mentioned in the complaint.

(2) Is it also a fact that the share ramping resulted in profits ranging between $20m and $30m; if so, (a) does the ASC consider this to be a serious complaint; if so, why has it not investigated the matter and (b) does the ASC treat large organisations like Country Natwest different to other organisations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2)(a) I am advised that the ASC received a complaint from lawyers acting for Cambridge Gulf Exploration NL, by letter dated 8 February 1996, concerning trading in the company's securities. The ASC commenced an investigation into this matter in April 1996. As the investigation has not yet been completed, it is not appropriate for me to comment on, or release information concerning, the complaint that was lodged or the resulting investigation.

2(b) I am advised that the answer is No. All entities operating in the securities markets, regardless of size, are subject to the Corporations Law. In particular, the market offence provisions of the Law apply to all entities and individuals dealing in the market.

The ASC is responsible for the administration of the Law. In discharging its responsibilities with regard to the investigation of alleged breaches of the Law, the ASC has a structured process for determining what action it will take. The criteria it takes account of include whether the alleged conduct is serious; affects the integrity of markets; generates a high level of public interest; or involves fraud or dishonesty on the part of company officers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: State and Territories Business Enterprises: Taxation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Commonwealth agreed to the States and Territories retaining the tax equivalent of Commonwealth tax liability on their business enterprises; if so, what are the details.

(2) Will the Government apply the same agreements referred to in part (1) to tax equivalents on local government business enterprises; if not, how can the national competition package overcome the tax disincentive to the corporatisation of certain local government functions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The taxation arrangements for State and Territory business enterprises were agreed at the March 1994 Premiers' Conference, and encapsulated in a "Statement of Policy Intent" (SOPI). In effect, the SOPI provides that:

PARA.TAB: the Commonwealth would legislate to exempt all state and territory trading enterprises from Commonwealth income tax and wholesale sales tax (WST);
state and territory governments retain the tax equivalent of Commonwealth tax liability for those enterprises which were not subject to Commonwealth income tax nor borne WST prior to 25 March 1994;

for enterprises that were subject to Commonwealth income tax or had borne WST prior to 25 March 1994, state and territory governments would pay compensation to the Commonwealth equivalent to the amount the Commonwealth would have collected in respect of that enterprise had it continued to be liable to tax.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The previous Government had not negotiated with the States, Territories and Local Government the application to Local Government Businesses of the set of principles encapsulated in SOPI. This Government has yet to address this matter.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association: Newspaper Article

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Australian Financial Review , dated 19 November 1996, entitled "Hand of Dick seen in missive" and referring to a letter sent to him from the Aircraft Owners and Plots Association (AOPA); is so, (a) did he receive the letter, (b) what was the date of the letter, (c) when was it received by his office (d) what did the letter contain and (e) will he provide a copy to Parliament.
(2) Is he able to say whether Dr Liddell's resignation letter was not delivered to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority until 9.15 am. on 18 November 1996.
(3) What formal and informal communications passed between AOPA and Dr Liddell since August 1996.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of the letter.
(a) Yes.
(b) 17 November 1996.
(c) The letter was stamped received in my office on 18 November 1996.
(d) The text of the letter is as follows:
Dear Minister

AOPA Australia is shocked to learn of the resignation of Dr Rob Liddell from the position of Director, Office of Aviation Medicine, Civil Aviation Safety Authority. Dr Liddell, the longest serving manager within CASA, is the very type of person CASA can ill afford to lose. As the administrator of aviation medical policy he has shown qualities that have stood him apart from the general tone of CASA's policy making mechanism. Dr Liddell brought a fresh approach to the Aviation Medicine Branch, no doubt in no small part due to his having worked as a line pilot in the airline industry.

His progressive philosophy has perhaps best been demonstrated by his policy towards pilots who have had coronary artery disease treated by bypass surgery. These pilots would in days past have been barred from further flying activities, but now they may be recertified fit to fly providing they pass certain medical criteria.

Dr Liddell has at all times been approachable to pilots and medical examiners alike, but always conscious of his obligation to the safety of the travelling public. He is open to arguments, and open to persuasion, provided the evidence be put logically. In short, he has approached his job in an open and forthright manner. Whilst AOPA does not always agree with the decisions made by Dr Liddell, he is respected by this Association for his integrity.

The letter of resignation reveals a deep crisis within CASA which likely goes far beyond the confines of the Office of Aviation Medicine. AOPA considers it a matter of extreme urgency , in the interest of the safety of aviation in this country, that the matters raised by Dr Liddell be addressed without delay. AOPA similarly, urges you, Minister, to use your influence to reverse Dr Liddell's decision to resign. If there are to be resignations, those who have brought about the crisis described by Dr Liddell should be leaving not the likes of Dr Liddell.
Sincerely
(e) See response to 1(d) above for the text of the letter.
(2) Dr Liddell's letter of resignation to Mr Keith was dated 15 November 1996 and was hand delivered to Mr Keith's office at 9.15 am on Monday 18 November 1996.
(3) CASA has no record of any formal communication between AOPA and Dr Liddell since August 1996. I am not privy to private communications and am unable to answer this part of the question.

The total number of aircraft movements (including a breakdown into the above categories) which occurred at Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne Airports in each month since July 1995 are as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Does (a) the Government have a policy of reducing interest rates and (b) the Australian Taxation Office charge 19.5 per cent on money due since the 1995 tax year; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) As indicated in my joint statement with the Governor of the Reserve Bank on 14 August 1996, the Government strongly supports the monetary policy framework which requires the Board of the Reserve Bank to set official interest rates with the objectives prescribed in the Reserve Bank's legislation. The Government has welcomed the three reductions in official interest rates which occurred in the second half of 1996.

(b) The automatic imposition of additional charges for late payment is a response, by way of legislation, aimed at encouraging payment of taxation debts by the due date. The additional charges also deny late payers an advantage over those who do pay on time.

For some taxes, an additional interest component operates to compensate the revenue for the loss suffered during the period the amounts were outstanding. This interest may be compared to what is acceptable commercial practice for use of funds and it is calculated on a base using the thirteen week Treasury Note rate of interest. (Hence, changes in market interest rates are reflected in the additional interest rate penalty, albeit with a lag.)
The charge for the late payment of an income tax, franking deficits tax and provisional tax debt consists of:‐
(i) a penalty component of 8% per annum; plus
(ii) a per annum interest component, based on the thirteen week Treasury Note rate plus four percentage points.

A new per annum interest component normally applies for a six month period, commencing on 1 January and 1 July each year and is published in the Gazette by the Commissioner of Taxation before the new rate takes effect. The rate for each period since the 1995 tax year is as follows:‐

PARA.TAB: July 1995 to December 1995 was—12.0% per annum
January 1996 to June 1996 was—11.5% per annum
July 1996 to December 1996 was—11.5% per annum
January 1997 to June 1997 is—10.5% per annum

ANSWER.PARA: The interest component of the additional charge paid to the Commissioner is allowable as a deduction to taxpayers in the year of income in which the interest is paid.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 10 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Telstra offer discounts to customers for local telephone calls; if so, (a) what discounts are offered, (b) since when have they been on offer, (c) do they apply in all States and (d) what percentage of customers in each State has applied for and is receiving discounts.
(2) Does Telstra advertise discounts available to local telephone calls; if so (a) how, (b) in which States is advertising conducted and (c) what does it cost in (i) total and (ii) each State.

(3) Has advertising in some States been greater than in others and resulted in higher utilisation of discounts in those States; if so, will Telstra offer retrospective discounts for customers who have been discriminated against through a lack of information.

(4) In which States does Telstra (a) have a monopoly on local calls and (b) face competition with local calls, and in those States in which it faces competition, what is the market share of each carrier in the local call market.
(5) Will Telstra consider giving all customers one of the applicable discounts; if not, why not.
(6) Will Telstra consider replacing the discount structure with an across the board reduction in the cost of local calls; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by Telstra:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(a) The following optional discount plans are available to customers for local telephone calls:

PARA.TAB: Local Call Saver 5%—provides a 5% discount once a threshold spend of $10 per month is reached. Local Call Saver is available to residential and business customers. This plan was previously known as Call Saver 5.

Local Call Saver 8%—provides a discount of 8% with the $25 a month threshold spend. It is available to business customers only. This plan was initially filed as Corporate Centre Local, and Call Saver 10.

Local Call Saver 15—the first $15 spend of calls per month receive no discount, the next $85 receive a 15% discount, and all remaining calls receive no discount. This Call Saver is available to residential customers only.

ANSWER.PARA: (b) Each of these plans became available as follows:

PARA.TAB: Call Saver 5—May 1993;
Call Saver 10—August 1995;
Corporate Centre Local—May 1995; and
Local Call Saver 15—February 1996.

ANSWER.PARA: (c) Yes—these plans apply in all States.
(d) Telstra regards this information as Commercial in Confidence.
(2) Yes. Telstra does advertise discounts applicable to local telephone calls.

(a) Telstra advertises its optional discounts under the general Flexi‐Plan brand in a range of mediums (for example, radio, television, press, magazines, phone books (see White Pages WA, page 29), press releases and telemarketing).
(b) All States have been included in the advertising.
(c) Telstra regards this information as Commercial in Confidence.
(3) Telstra's advertising has generally been on a national basis.

Telstra regards information on the take‐up rates of services as Commercial in Confidence, however, Western Australia actually has a higher penetration than other States for optional discount plans for local calls.

Telstra has actively marketed discount plans using methods such as inbound and outbound telemarketing, shopping centre displays and sales representatives visiting customers. As Telstra has widely promoted these plans to eligible customers, Telstra does not consider it has been discriminating in these actions.
(4) Both general carriers, Telstra and Optus, and service providers operating under the Service Providers Class Licence, are permitted to provide, and/or resell, local call services.
Telstra regards information on market share as Commercial in Confidence.
(5) The discount plans are available to customers on the bases noted against question (1).

Telstra has promoted plans in a variety of ways (see answer to question 2). Telstra does not believe that automatically bestowing the plans is an appropriate strategy. Telstra's experience is that customers take exception to Telstra automatically placing Flexi‐Plan or other pricing packages on their accounts without their knowledge or consent.

(6) No. Telstra prefers to offer customers a choice of plans that allow them to select options that best meet their overall communications needs. For the reasons outlined in response to question (5), this approach is believed to be consistent with customer requirements. This approach is used by Telstra's competitors in Australia, and is the general practice in other countries where optional calling plans are offered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is his Department responsible for the conservation of historic wartime sites apart from war graves?
(2) Has he received representations about the deteriorating condition of the Gallipoli historic site and in particular the Australian trenches?
(3) Has he sought and obtained a report on the condition of the Gallipoli site, if so what are the findings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Apart from the War Cemeteries in Australia and Papua New Guinea, the only historic wartime sites for which my Department, through the Office of Australian War Graves, is responsible are certain sites of very limited extent in which have been erected Australian Battle Exploit Memorials. Typical among these are the Bullecourt Memorial Park and the `Windmill Site' at Pozires on the Western Front of Northern France.
(2) I have received representations from persons who have visited Gallipoli in the recent past. Those representations have noted the weathered state of the battlefield earth works.

(3) I obtained the advice of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission regarding the status and condition of the Gallipoli Battlefield. The battlefield sites at Gallipoli are contained within a Turkish National Park. The Commonwealth War Cemeteries that have been established on Gallipoli are the responsibility of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission with its Head Office in London and with resident maintenance staff in the Gallipoli area.
The main area of the Gallipoli battlefield today bears a close resemblance to the rugged unspoilt landscape that confronted the ANZAC's on 25 April 1915.

Since establishment of the war cemeteries on Gallipoli in the 1920s the Commonwealth War Graves Commission has taken the view that the battlefield should be allowed to remain in its natural state and that no attempt should be made to preserve or reconstruct the wartime earth works. That approach was adopted in respectful recognition of the blood that has been shed on those battlefields and the many symbols of tragedy that the earth contains. The Commission takes the view that to allow the battlefield to remain as far as possible in its natural state is to lend added dignity to the many war cemeteries that are contained within it.

The Turkish Government has recently invited the ANZAC nations to join with it in establishing a Peace Park on Gallipoli that would include the ANZAC battlefields. Should that proposal envisage restoration of any features of the battlefield, the Australian Government, in consultation with our New Zealand and British colleagues, would be prepared to consider such development.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the reporting structure from Emergency Management Australia to the Prime Minister in the event of a national emergency.
(2) When was the current reporting structure introduced.
(3) Has the structure changed; if so, (a) what was the prior reporting structure, (b) why was it changed and (c) who requested the change.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My office is informed whenever there is a possibility that the States or Territories might request Commonwealth physical assistance to deal with an emergency. Once a formal request is received, EMA seeks my approval. EMA has no direct reporting chain to the Prime Minister, however, the Disaster Service Liaison Officer within the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet is provided with timely advice on national emergencies.
(2) The reporting procedure was introduced with the establishment of the Natural Disasters Organisation (now Emergency Management Australia) in 1974.

(3) The reporting system remains unchanged. However, as a result of the recent experience gained during the Mars Space Probe incident, officials are more acutely aware of the need for timely advice to Government of emergency or disaster events which would involve a response by the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) bands and (b) band members are there in the (i) Navy, (ii) Army and (iii) Air Force.
(2) Does the Government plan to reduce the number of (a) bands and (b) band members in the Services; if so, which bands will be affected and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a)(i) Navy—There are two permanent Navy bands; one in Sydney, the other in Melbourne. The Navy also has six Naval Reserve bands which are located in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Fremantle, Hobart and Brisbane.

(ii) Army—There are 10 regional Army bands. Five of these are Australian Regular Army bands which are located in Canberra, Sydney, Brisbane, Kapooka and Melbourne. The other five are General Reserve bands located in Perth, Adelaide, Hobart, Darwin and Newcastle.
(iii) Air Force—The Air Force has two bands.

(b)(i) Navy—The permanent bands have a total complement of 91 personnel against an authorised strength of 98, while the Reserve bands have a complement of 109 personnel against an authorised strength of 144 personnel.
(ii) Army—There are currently 208 Australian Regular Army musicians against an authorised strength of 208.

The five General Reserve regional bands are authorised to employ a total of 158 members. This number is influenced by the recruitment/resignation rates from the General Reserve, however, the number is generally close to this figure.

In addition to the 10 regional Army bands, there are 19 Army Reserve units which have an integral band of up to 25 personnel. However, these personnel have an operational role within their parent units and are not therefore considered to be full‐time band members.
(iii) Air Force—The RAAF Central Band which has 33 personnel, and the Air Command Band which has 50 personnel.
(2)(a)(b) There are no plans in place to review Defence bands. However, this is an area which may be addressed by the Defence Efficiency Review. The Government will assess all Defence Efficiency
Review proposals once the report of the Senior Review Panel is handed to the Minister for Defence on March 10, 1997.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does his Department own, lease or otherwise occupy land in the vicinity of the Canungra Land Warfare Centre known as Killarney Glen.
(2) Was or is this land owned by the Fitzgerald family.
(3) Do any Fitzgerald family members currently live on the property; if so, under what arrangements.
(4) Does his Department have any plans for the area; if so, what.
(5) Is the area currently Heritage listed; if not, is his Department aware of a proposed listing.
(6) What advice has his Department provided to the Australian Heritage Commission regarding a possible listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The Department of Defence compulsorily acquired 25 properties in the vicinity of the Land Warfare Centre at Canungra in 1971. The property previously known as Killarney Glen was one of those acquired.
(2) The land was acquired from Mr P M Fitzgerald.

(3) It is understood that family members occasionally live on the property. Defence has agreed to allow Mr P M Fitzgerald to continue to occupy the area referred to as Killarney Glen for as long as he has a personal need for the property. This arrangement is not transferable to other members of his family.

(4) Defence has recently constructed additional training ranges to the north of the area in question. The area which was Killarney Glen is now designated as part of the buffer zone surrounding the new range areas.

(5) Except for the administration and accommodation area, and a small area of about fifteen hundred square metres in the south east sector of the training area, all of the Land Warfare Centre, including the area in question, is currently listed on the Register of the National Estate.

(6) In November 1996, the Australian Heritage Commission advised Defence of the intention to separately list the area described as the Back Creek Landscape and sought comment as appropriate. Defence indicated that it had no objection to the proposed listing but did seek to clarify the incorrect inference that Killarney Glen and Land Warfare Centre were two separate properties. The Heritage Commission has now indicated its agreement with the Defence position. This new listing will result in a segment of Land Warfare Centre appearing in two separate listings in the Register of the National Estate.
